I think Whatsapp never had your messages on their side anyways, that's the reason why their Whatsapp WebApp required your mobile phone to be online because they were relaying the connection to your phone to send\receive and read messages, I haven't had chance to go into details but I think the only difference now is your data is encrypted on message by message basis not only relying on transport level encryption as in SSL and it is also encrypted on your phone at rest (which may have been the case already)

ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§ ÙƒØ§Ù† Ù‡ÙŠØ¨Ù‚Ù‰ peer to peer Ø¨Ù‚Ù‰..  ÙˆØ¯Ù‡ Ø·Ø¨Ø¹Ø§ Ù…Ø´ Ø­Ù‚ÙŠÙ‚ÙŠ

This has nothing to do with you being able to access your whatsapp's media locally. They would never encrypt your media to let other apps (Google Photos for instance) access them. Your local messages db is encrypted with a key that you can only access as a root, that's why other apps can access your media but not your messages.
As Mohamed Elsherif mentioned, end to end encryption is just another layer of security other than SSL. It just prevents whatsapp (and third parties) from having access to your messages on their part not yours. Messages leaving your mobile (your end) are encrypted and can only be decrypted on the receiver's phone(the other end). End to end encryption. But SSL for sure has been there from the beginning, otherwise your ISP (or even a second year CS student in a public network) could have been reading your conversations while they are on the wire.

I was about to ask about Key Exchange and how can we trust that we're using the other person's actual key (and not a man-in-the-middle), but then I realized that the ability to scan the other person's QR is a way to verify that you have the correct key. I like this system, a nice mix of simplicity and security :)
